Describe and evaluate one of the competitors’ advertising messages from Section 3

To start off, CeraVe uses a cognitive generic message strategy to advertise their products. In the “CeraVe…with Michael Cera…Ve” commercial they use Michael Cera to highlight the benefits from using CeraVe. They combine their science- based claims, dermatologist endorsements and overall educational content to connect with consumers. Throughout the commercial CeraVe can be seen promoting their product by emphasizing their attributes and benefits. They made sure to specify what the qualities of the product are and how that can benefit the consumer.

CeraVe uses a mix of rationality and humor appeals for their advertising message. In the Michael Cera commercial, Michael Cera is seen using the moisturizer in humorous scenarios. This would include giving someone a massage, rubbing the moisturizer on the mountain and even talking to a dolphin about having moisturized skin. While the commercial showcased their product in humorous ways, they made sure to include a rational and educational approach. Michael Cera mentions throughout the commercial that there are “Three essential ceramides” and “All day hydration” to assure viewers about the benefits of using the product. Ultimately, ending the commercial with “Developed with Dermatologists, Not Michael Cera” to make sure the viewers knew that there was credibility behind the product.

Finally, the executional approach used by CeraVe is the Informative approach. The commercial focused on educating the audience by providing details about the product. CeraVe specifically focused on proving why their moisturizer was reliable and why the viewers should also use it. A panel of dermatologists was included in the commercial to show their disapproval of Michael Cera claiming he was the one who created CeraVe. To end the commercial, with a reassurance to viewers that it was actually developed with dermatologists.

Develop a message strategy to support your positioning

Message Strategy

A cognitive unique selling proposition is a useful message strategy when wanting to communicate what sets our product apart from our competitors. This strategy especially aims for our consumers who value logic, facts, and proven benefits. Our target audience of 45 to 54 year olds are at the age where making smart decisions is crucial, so using this strategy will help them feel confident that they are making the right choice choosing Bubble. With many skincare brands targeting the same group, our audience has many different options to choose from and may get overwhelmed. Highlighting what differentiates Bubble with a standout feature or benefit will bring our products front and center. Cognitive unique selling proposition helps consumers during the decision process. This feature can lead the consumers to choose Bubble while comparing it to its competitors.

A cognitive hyperbole is preferred to catch a consumer's attention. Using a hyperbole is a great way to break through all the advertising clutter. By adding a bold, exaggerated phrase, it will make the product sound dramatic, exciting, and effective. This strategy is also quite simple to use since the claim is not testable. For the company to say whatever they please without needing to prove it is much easier than having to gather facts. By using a hyperbole, Bubble will be able to communicate much faster in a short amount of time. With all the clutter of advertisements, brands only have a few seconds to stand out, so by using this strategy, Bubble will take advantage of that short time frame. Our target demographic have busy lives with careers, family, and personal struggles, so getting straight to the point with our advertisement will be highly effective. Making a strong impression will allow consumers to recall Bubble rather than other brands. Our age demographic have seen many advertisements displaying factual claims, so by having a creative phrase instead, the message will be more effective and resonate well.

An affective-emotional message strategy is a powerful way for Bubble to resonate with people ages 45-54 years old to tap into their memories. It creates an emotional approach to remind them of their youthful years and the beauty and wisdom that comes with aging. Through nostalgic imagery, Bubble will evoke memories from the past such as an older woman in our age demographic looking at her younger self in a mirror and reminiscing on the past. Memories such as getting ready for a first date or feeling invincible in your twenties are memories that are meant to be paired with the feeling of having fresh and taken care of skin. By utilizing nostalgia and self acceptance, our target audience will gravitate toward a brand such as Bubble that will focus on making them feel like their younger self while loving their current self. Bubble understands the emotional journey that comes with aging and by using the affective-emotional strategy, they will be able to draw in our target demographic by remembering their past, encouraging their present, and protecting their future.

Appeal

Bubble’s advertising appeals aims to tap into our target demographic's emotions, fear, and rationale to create a more personal and deeper connection to the brand. By focusing on the emotional appeal, we highlight the desire many women aged 45–54 have, which is to feel youthful, radiant, and confident in their skin. This appeal will attract many of the demographic’s attention by attracting those who want to feel good in their current skin while feeling a sense of youthfulness. Our age demographic will resonate with Bubble’s skin care due to how the brand’s emotional appeal does not simply focus on appearance but rather self-care and well-being. This appeal can focus on the nostalgic feeling of looking like their younger self while reclaiming a sense of vibrance and rejuvenation.

Utilizing the appeal of fear can attract our target audience and gravitate them towards buying products due to it focusing on a pressing situation which is the risks that come with neglecting skin health. People ages 45-54 years old often face many struggles  with the coming of age, most specifically with thinner, drier, and more vulnerable skin barrier damage. This could lead to problems such as wrinkles, dark sports, sagging, and in severe cases, cancer. Our fear appeal is not aimed to scare our target audience, but instead create a sense of urgency to prevent this from occurring. It will be used as an empowering way to motivate our customers that Bubble can be a solution to these problems that most people are scared of in this age bracket. Ultimately, the fear approach will be used to tap into the audience's desire to regain some control over their skin.

A rational appeal is best to use when attempting to gain the trust of our target audience by highlighting specific results and benefits of Bubble’s products. Creating a message that talks about SPS protections, antioxidants, chemical alternatives and other ingredients informs the customers of what Bubble includes in their products. After addressing the ingredients, customers are able to see if those qualities will satisfy their certain needs. All the ingredients have a certain purpose and will become a solution to certain areas such as the SPS protection will be used to reduce sun spots and skin cancers. This presents logical evidence due to it being clinically tested, potentially dermatologist approved, real testimonies and other factual evidence that wins over the trust of Bubble’s potential customers.

Executional Strategy

        An authoritative executional strategy builds immediate trust and credibility. By using an expert such as a doctor or dermatologist to describe our product’s benefits backs up our claims. These experts have studied to receive the authority they have today, so if they support our product, it will be difficult for our consumers to not trust its benefits. Skincare is a sensitive subject for our target age demographic, so credible authority reassures skeptical consumers that our product actually works. This strategy will also elevate our brand’s perceived quality; presenting the product through an authoritative tone will position our brand as premium. Professional assurance is always beneficial in advertising for this age group since they have been presented with many promises over the years. Tapping into an important consumer need such as safety gives them confidence that it is appropriate for their skin and increases their trust, leading them to choose Bubble.

        Slice-of-life executional strategy aims to portray different components of what our age demographic faces in their daily lives. It will illustrate the common struggle many people feel after waking up, heading to the mirror, and encountering a distaste in their appearance that they desire to change. This problem will then turn into an interaction by figuring out what solutions can resolve the issue, and by turning to Bubble skincare as a solution, they are able to find products that will naturally fit into their skincare routine. After adapting this into their skincare routine, it can portray our target audience's slight positive mood switches when finding the correct skincare that will fall in line with their routines.

        A demonstration strategy will be highly effective in showing our target audience how and why the product works. One of the benefits of this strategy is showing a step-by-step process of how to use the product as well as visible changes in appearances. It will portray an easy and clear routine for people 45-54 years old to follow, which avoids confusion and helps them achieve the skincare goals they desire. Advertisement results that will motivate our audience will illustrate clearer skin, reduce fine lines, calm purple circles and eye bags, and other visible changes. In order to gain the trust of customers, models in the advertisement could be more diverse and less picture-perfect to give a greater sense of reality when portraying what the products do. By utilizing the demonstration strategy, this will be able to show the logical proof that consumers in our age demographic desire to see when buying a product.

Chosen Combination

        An affective-emotional, rational, and demonstrative approach would be the strongest combination for Bubble’s ad campaigns because it balances the emotional connection to our target market while also providing proof. First, the affective-emotional aspect of the ad will tap into the nostalgic feeling that will immediately establish a bond. Customers enjoy when brands are capable of understanding their problems and providing a solution. Second, once the emotional connection is made, the rational component is needed. Consumers in our target market of 45- 54 year olds may be skeptical and much harder to convince to buy a product. So, by providing the logic and evidence to support our product, the consumers will have more of a reason to feel confident in their purchase. Lastly, with both emotion and rationality included in our ads, the final step is to contribute demonstration to pull it all together. Displaying the product in action will visually demonstrate its benefits. Showing real people applying the product and seeing visible results will provide the consumers with the knowledge that the results are achievable and tangible. Affective-emotional targets our consumers' hearts, while rational targets their brains, and demonstration targets their eyes. Together, this combination creates an emotional, informative, and persuasive message that will convince our target market to purchase Bubble’s products.

Produce 3 original examples of executions in line with your message strategy.

        Our campaign promise, “Glow like the good old days,” is featured as the center of the billboard advertisement with our Bubble products lined up beside it. This slogan was crafted to resonate specifically with our target audience of people who are 45 to 54 who want skin that feels as vibrant as it once did, sparking immediate nostalgia. We encouraged readability by keeping a minimal word count, and using warm high contrast colors across all of our advertisements. This strategic use of warm colors across all the Bubble Skincare advertisements and a nostalgic theme is done so to strengthen brand recall across our audience. The concept of the billboard is a mature hand reaching for the Overnight Hydrating Serum, as we expect this to be our most popular product for our target audience, with a concise message stating our products are “Made with plant based extracts and dermatologist recommended”. This adds instant credibility, and encourages passengers to look further into our brand.

In an effort to produce digitized advertisements while remaining loyal to audience preferences, the next advertisement is a facebook ad. The target audience is familiar with Facebook, considering it is one of the most popular social media platforms among older people. We chose to incorporate the products on a small pedestal to showcase the products names and bottle information with their new packaging and logo. We also included the picture of the mature lady with her younger self in the background to convey the nostalgia to the target audience. This visual aid helps to show that these products are designed to help skin look and feel youthful at any age. As well, we had the older lady putting on some skincare on her face to demonstrate her using the products because it will carry the message that Bubble Skincare products are also for older mature skin. With that said, we used many neutral beige brown colors in the advertisement, since it conveys a more elegant and mature look to the ad. Lastly, we included the slogan “Glow Like The Good Old Days” because we want to bring that nostalgic emotion back to the audience.

For our final choice of advertisement we decided to do a magazine spread with a tight “before” shot of a woman’s eye showcasing some aging with prominent wrinkles. Beside it, an identically framed “after” photo reveals smoother skin and a more even tone, proving at a glance that our formulas deliver real results. We placed them side by side to draw the attention of our audience to understand our products are science based for the best results. This was to be impactful to our audience of 45-54 year olds, who value evidence based. This strategy acted as logical and demonstrative, since the image shows the product's effects. Next, we added a tray with our products to the top right corner so customers could picture the products sitting on their vanities and becoming a part of their daily lives and once again demonstrate the benefits of incorporating Bubble Skincare. Finally in the bottom left corner, we have text explaining the benefits of using our skincare, since it is made to keep you looking and feeling your best. This magazine leans on both emotional nostalgia and rational proof in a single glance.

Develop a media plan to support your advertising strategy.

To reach the 44–54-year-old audience, Bubble Skincare is planning a full national advertising campaign. This fits with the brand’s goal of bringing a sense of nostalgia while showing that their products really work. The 44–54 age group, often called Generation X, “exhibit a versatile blend, balancing traditional and digital mediums” (MediaCulture, 2023). They appreciate brands that feel genuine and offer both quality products and a real experience they can connect with. A national approach will help Bubble reach people in different parts of the country, making sure the brand stays visible and relatable.

The plan is to aim for about three exposures per person over a four-week stretch. This follows the “effective frequency” idea, which says people usually need to see an ad at least three times for it to stick. Studies also show that digital ads sometimes need a few more views to be remembered, but not so many that it gets annoying. As advertising expert Nigel Hollis puts it, “The rule of thumb for digital appears to be around 7” exposures to really make an impact (Hollis, 2022). Based on our goals and how this group uses media, a pulsating schedule would work better than a constant one. It means having some periods with a lot of ads and others with fewer, keeping Bubble in people's minds without wearing them out.

To connect with this audience, Bubble will use a mix of traditional and non-traditional media channels. Television is still big with this group, with many watching more than two hours a day. Ads placed during news programs and lifestyle shows will likely get the best attention. We’ll also run ads in magazines like Good Housekeeping and People, since these are popular and trusted with this age group. Outdoor advertising like billboards, wallscapes, and train station display ads in busy areas will also help build brand recognition by showing off product visuals in a bold way.

Non-traditional media is just as important for this campaign. Platforms like Hulu, Peacock, and HBO Max are becoming more popular with adults in this age group and are great places for video ads that show off the product in action. Facebook and Instagram are still widely used by this demographic too, both for staying connected with friends and discovering new brands. We will also invest in paid search ads so that when people research skincare products online, Bubble appears as a trusted and visible option. We’ll use a mix of paid ads and posts on our own accounts to stay top of mind. Sharing emotional content and product demos will encourage interaction and get people talking about the brand.

To really bring the campaign to life, we’re also planning a “Feel Young Again” event. This will be a fun, hands-on experience with skincare consultations, product demos, and a chance for people to interact with the brand in person. As The Event Company says, “By crafting memorable experiences, brands can forge deeper, more emotional connections with their audience, turning fleeting interactions into lasting impressions” (The Event Company, 2023). We plan to hold the event after the first wave of ads runs, using the excitement we build to drive even more attention. A “Mommy and Me” theme will invite mothers and their adult children to spend time together while trying the products, tying into the idea of feeling youthful again. This event will help Bubble build stronger relationships with a new audience and encourage people to actually try the products for themselves.

Budget

Billboards 

        We budgeted $174,825 for seven billboards and one wallscape in high-traffic cities like Los Angeles, San Diego, Dallas, San Antonio, Tampa, Orlando, and Las Vegas. Each billboard campaign will last four weeks. In Los Angeles, we allocated $30,000 ("Billboard Advertising in Los Angeles", 2025) for one digital and one bulletin board near the LAX freeway to reach drivers during heavy traffic. In San Diego, we spent $10,500 ("Billboard Advertising in San Diego", 2025) for a digital board near Petco Park. In Texas, we budgeted $18,800 ("Billboard Advertising in Texas", 2025) for one board in San Antonio near a zoo and one in Dallas near downtown. For Florida, we spent $15,525 ("Billboard Advertising in Florida", 2025) to place one board near Disneyland in Orlando and one near the Tampa airport.

Wallscapes 

        We set aside $100,000 ("Billboard Advertising in Las Vegas", 2025) for a hotel wallscape near the Strip in Las Vegas, where it will stand out to tourists and foot traffic.

Magazine 

        We are investing $385,600 in a national, four-color, full-page ad in PEOPLE magazine because its latest media kit shows that 60% of readers are between the ages 45 to 55, which is the perfect target audience (PEOPLE, 2024). With a weekly magazine that delivers repeated impressions, this placement offers high-value reach and credibility during our rebrand. In addition, there will also be a full-page placement in Good Housekeeping that will cost $260,000 and reach 4.7 million readers (Good Housekeeping, 2025).

Logo Redesign 

        We will be spending $10,000 on logo resign because our goal is to rebrand our logo to fit our age demographic more. The idea is to create a more mature and basic persona in order to appeal to our older target audience. We wanted to go with a more high end logo which is why we are willing to spend more money on ensuring the brand “can stand out in a good way,” (“Logo Design Pricing: How Much Does a Logo Design Cost?: Vistaprint US.”). One of the most important things when having a business is logo recognition which will make our “business… look polished and credible,” (“Logo Design Pricing: How Much Does a Logo Design Cost?: Vistaprint US.”).

Website Redesign 

        We will spend $75,000 on a website redesign since we are rebranding our logo and packaging products, which eventually will also affect our website design. Having a well-designed website that correlates with your logo and packaging is important, since it “plays a vital role in attracting and retaining customers” (Leach, 2025). As well, the cost of a website redesign is caused by many factors such as “the size, complexity, design quality, content, and any additional features” (Leach, 2025). With that said, spending a good amount on high-quality website redesigning can help us attract new customers like our target audience, and retain our current customers.

Packaging Redesign 

        We will spend $400,000 on packaging redesign since we are rebranding to target 45-54 year olds. We allocated our spending amount based on our brand's revenue. Large companies like Bubble “may spend more than 8% of revenue” for their rebranding, since they would have a “wider product range and more customers” (Sandel, 2023). As well, it is important to spend a large amount of money on packaging, since it is found “that 72% of shoppers are influenced by packaging design” (Sandel, 2023). With that said, it is important for us to spend on high-quality new packaging, since we will be targeting an older, mature audience.

Brand Event

        We will spend $1 million on the brand event for Bubble. After reading, “What Does it Really Cost to Launch a Beauty Product Today?” different founders mention how a launch party can range from $200,000 to $1.2 million. Which led to the decision of spending $1 million as our spending budget.

Branded Posts 

        We will be spending $250,000 for Facebook macro influencers and $12,500 for micro influencers. We will then be spending $100,000 for Instagram macro influencers and $50,000 for micro influencers. With that being said, the article “Influencer Marketing Costs 2025:  Influencer Rates per Channel” mentions these charges differ by app and can be from $5,000 to over $10,000 per post. Therefore, the budget reflects how much would be spent overall in paying influencers micro and macro for multiple posts through a time period of 4 weeks.

Streaming 

        One of the best ways for Bubble to get noticed is during the few seconds of advertisements on streaming services. Our goal is to invest $300,000 on Hulu, $440,000 on Peacock and $530,000 on HBO because we felt like these channels were the most likely to get recognition from potential customers in our age demographic. Younger generation seem to prefer streaming services such as Netflix and Disney Plus, where our chosen streaming services have more people ages 45-54 years old watching. Although spending a good portion of our budget on this, we kept it relatively smaller due to “the market is beginning to even out as advertisers spread their spending around,” (Connelly, Eileen AJ).         

Paid Search 

        We will invest $40,000 in Google Ads for our budget since 45% of advertisers spend up to $10,000 per month, with most paying $0.11–$0.50 per click (WebFX, 2025). In addition, we intend to spend $60,000 to Amazon Sponsored Products, an investment Amazon says is beneficial for brands seeking visibility in crowded marketplaces (Amazon Advertising, 2024).

Television 

        Spending $500,000 on television advertising for Bubble is a strategic decision to reach a larger audience. According to industry-wide data, “for national prime-time programming, a 30-second spot can range from $200,000 to $500,000” (Sheikh, 2024). By allocating this budget price on television, Bubble may secure a nice slot and time frame to ensure exposure to our target market of 45-54 year olds. Focusing on channels such as Fox 11, ABC, and NBC would be the most effective since our target demographic frequently watches these channels.

New York Subway

        Spending $40,000 on a New York Subway advertising campaign for Bubble is an effective way to capitalize on the high volume of traffic the form of transportation generates. Advertising in the subway “has a huge range from $5,000 per 4 weeks to well over $60,000 per 4 weeks for system wide buys. There are many choices, some targeted such as platform posters and urban panels and some system wide such as platform showing levels and interior car card buys” (Inspiria Outdoor Advertising). With this budget, Bubble can utilize the car card buys for 4 weeks that will provide continuous exposure.
